topRanked.articleTitle: Sponge-dwelling snapping shrimps of Curaçao, with descriptions of three new species *
topRanked.articleAuthor: Hultgren, Kristin M., Macdonald Iii, Kenneth S. & Duffy, J. Emmett
topRanked.summary: Synalpheus williamsi is a species of polychaete worm found in the canals of Hymeniacidon caerulea, characterized by its bright orange coloration and brown-tipped major chelae. It is primarily found in heterosexual pairs and has been reported in Belize, Jamaica, and Curaçao. The worms often have traces of their host sponge visible in their gut.

images.captionText: PLATE 6. A, Synalpheus ul non-ov. individual (VIMS 08CU2502) from Xestospongia subtriangularis, St. Michiel Baai, Curaçao; B, Synalpheus ul non-ov. individual (VIMS 08CU3302), from Hymeniacidon caerulea, Caracas Baai, Curaçao; C, Synalpheus ul ov. female (VIMS 08CU3303) from Hymeniacidon caerulea, Caracas Baai, Curaçao; D, Synalpheus ul ov. female (VIMS 08CU11301) from Xestospongia subtriangularis, Caracas Baai, Curaçao; E, Synalpheus williamsi non-ov. individual (VIMS 08CU4601) from Hymeniacidon caerulea, Westpunt, Curaçao; F, Synalpheus williamsi ov. female (VIMS 08CU4602) from Hymeniacidon caerulea, Westpunt, Curaçao.

response.answer: Zicrona caerulea is found in the canals of Hymeniacidon caerulea, specifically in Curaçao and Belize. It is also occasionally found in Jamaica.
